captions.text:
The Higgs Boson Part I: What it is and why
it matters

Let's cut to the chase: as of July 4, 2012,
the Higgs Boson is the last fundamental piece

of the Standard Model of Particle Physics
to be discovered experimentally. "But," you

might ask, "why was the Higgs Boson included
in the Standard Model alongside well-known

particles like electrons and photons and quarks
if it hadn't been discovered back then in

the 1970s?" Good question. There are two main
reasons:

First, just like the electron is an excitation
in the electron field, the Higgs boson is

simply a particle which is an excitation of
the everywhere-permeating Higgs field. The

Higgs field, in turn, plays an integral role
in our model for radioactive decay, called

the weak nuclear force (in particular, the
Higgs field helps explain why it's so weak).

We'll talk more about this in a later video,
but even though weak nuclear theory was confirmed

in the 1980s, in the equations the Higgs field
is so inextricably jumbled with the weak force

that until now we've been unable to confirm
its actual and independent existence.

The second reason to include the Higgs in
the standard model is some jargony business

about the Higgs field giving all other particles
mass. But why does stuff need to be "given"

mass in the first place? Isn't mass just an
intrinsic property of matter, like electric

charge? Well, in particle physics…no. Remember
that in the Standard Model, we first write

down a mathematical "ingredients list" of
all the particles that we think are in nature

(and their properties). You can watch my "theory
of everything" video for a quick refresher.

We then run this list through a big fancy
mathematical machine, which spits out equations
that tell us how these particles behave.

Except, if we try to include mass as a property
for the particles on our ingredients list,

the math-machine breaks. Maybe mass was a
poor choice… but most particles we observe

in nature do have mass, so we have to figure
out some clever way of using ingredients that

will spit out mass in the final equations
without it being an input - kind of like how

you can let yeast, sugar and water ferment
into alcohol that wasn't there to begin with.

And as you may be thirstily anticipating,
the solution is to toss a yeasty Higgs field

in with the other ingredients of the Standard
Model, so that when we let the math ferment,

we get out particles that have mass! But this
model also brews up something we DIDN'T intend:

a solitary Higgs particle, the infamous boson.
And since the model works so well to explain

everything else, we figured it was pretty
likely that the lonely boson is right, too!

To summarize, the Higgs Boson is a particle
which is a left-over excitation of the Higgs

field, which in turn was needed in the Standard
Model to 1) explain the weak nuclear force

and 2) explain why any of the other particles
have mass at all. However, the boson is the

only bit of the Higgs field which is independently
verifiable, precisely because the other bits

are tangled up in the weak nuclear force and
in giving particles mass. The fact that the

Higgs Boson is so independent from the rest
of the Standard Model is why it's the last

piece of the puzzle to be discovered - and
if it turns out to be exactly what was predicted,
the Standard model will be complete.

The only problem is that we know that the
standard model ISN'T a complete description

of the universe (it entirely misses out on
gravity, for example). So to physicists, it

would be much more interesting AND helpful
if the Higgs boson turns out to be not quite

what we expect… then we might get a clue
as to how to reach a deeper understanding

of the universe. So even though we just made
a discovery, we can't sit back and relax.
We need a hint, Mr. Higgs.
Continued in Parts II and III

comments.text:
If the Biggs boson is the reason atoms have mass, then surely if you could 
remove it then they would be massless atoms? If so they could theoretically 
travel the speed of light as only massless objects can do that. Therefore 
if you could remove all the Biggs boson particles from a human, could they 
break the light barrier? Or would science happen and make you disintegrate 
or something?﻿

comments.author: johnathan clark

comments.text:
Its not exactly true that no (fundamental) particle can inherent mass (mass 
that doesn't come from interaction with some other field of non-zero VEV), 
its just that any gauge boson cannot be massive on its own (which was a big 
trouble in early development of electroweak theory since W bosons were 
massive) unless Higgs mechanism gives it effective mass via spontaneous 
symmetry breaking. 
Infact its much more likely that dark matter doesn't get its mass from the 
higgs and simply has a mass or gets it from a different higgs or both of 
these. ﻿

comments.text:
It seems as though before the big bang, whatever existed (the 
pre-universe), had the potential to transition to a lower energy state. 
Like a boulder at the top of a mountain, it can roll down the mountain and 
convert its gravitation potential energy into kinetic (movement) energy; 
and crash into someone's house.

So, the "pre-universe" "rolled down" and created the universe in the big 
bang. 

Maybe.

Perhaps the creation of space is how that energy is "paid" for. So, perhaps 
energy/space-time is conserved, but energy is only conserved at our 
everyday scales.

It is also possible that there is an infinite amount of energy, like a 
mountain with no bottom. So, locally energy cannot be created or destroyed, 
but big picture it is sometimes possible to get further down the mountain 
and liberate vast quantities of energy. Like more than the visible universe 
amounts of energy, which I probably do not need to say is a lot, which it 
is.

comments.author: Arthur Rondia (alphaLone)

comments.text:
The W+, W- and Z bosons interact with the Higgs field and acquire mass. 
This means that they are a short range force, unlike electromagnetic field 
which is a long range force.

How does having mass make something a short range force I hear you ask. 
Well, a force is described by quantum field theory as many virtual 
(borrowed energy) bosons being emitted by a particle "bumping" into other 
particles. So two electrons can be thought of as particles emitting many 
virtual photons. It is the virtual photons pushing against the other 
electron that means that electrons repel.
The more energy that the virtual photon has the less time it can exist for, 
it essentially exists on borrowed time, and the amount of time is inversely 
proportional to the amount of energy that it has. This is why there is a 
strong repulsion when electrons are close, i.e. the virtual photons with 
more borrowed energy still exist to push at close range. At greater 
distances it is only the lower energy photons that can exist for that long 
to push the other electron, so the force is weaker (all of the high energy 
photons have stopped existing at this range). Because photons do not have a 
rest mass, very very low energy photons can exist at very long distances 
away from the electron generating them and so can exert a force at long 
distances.
Because W bosons already have mass, there is a set maximum time they can 
exist for, therefore they can never act at a great distance. They cannot 
afford it, virtual energy wise.
Does this sound really weird? Well it is a bit of a simplification and it 
is also just weird.

comments.author: electrocat1

comments.text:
There is a charge exchange particle. the gluon is not affected by strong 
force, but it's still the exchange particle for the strong force. Also, how 
is "A particle responsible for the charge of paricles" not mean the 
exchange particle of charge. The higgs boson is the exchange particle for 
gravity, much as W+ or W- for weak force, every force has to have an 
exchange particle. For charge, it is the virtual photon. Please listen to 
yourself... this is GCSE physics...
comments.author: Arctic Venom

comments.text:

Besides, a photon itself has zero charge. There is no charge exchange 
particle.

where computers didn't even exist and tv's were barely being introduced 
when you grew up. Everyone looks back at what they grew up with and thinks 
that's all anyone should need. I'm in my 20's. I grew up seeing technology 
and science evolve as a kid. You were an adult when this huge boom in 
technology and science happened. You're a stubborn old guy and you may 
think world hunger is a bigger priority than crazy scientific endeavors but 
science has solved most issues. Most of the world isn't hungry. The only 
issue that has come with science is that most people aren't scientifically 
literate and are unable to see where it is going nor do they care. You're 
living in a time now where we are working with stem cells to make extra 
organs in case ours fail, we have the ability to correct eyesight, solar 
panels, and more. That should mean something to you, unfortunately all you 
seem to do is blame science.

comments.text:
A singularity is where a theory breaks apart. Like the center of a black 
hole where general relativity breaks apart. And we need a bigger theory to 
explain it because we know general relativity is just a great 
approximation. It's not a singular point but a region where we don't know 
what to do.
'Special' in special relativity doesn't mean something extraordinarily 
distinct (as in human life is special), but merely a case where certain 
simplifications are put forward. (As in : general relativity explains 
motion, but in the 'special case' of non-accelerating references, you get 
special relativity).

+Luapix Special relativity is a special case within general relativity - 
it's basicly GR without curvature of space time. GR says that 
energy&momentum "bend" spacetime - that's how gravity is explained for 
instance. The standard model is constructed so that it's consistent with 
special relativity and it is able to explain the strong&weak force as well 
as electromagnetism, but it not gravity. F****** mindblowin stuff... :)
comments.author: James Bro

comments.text:
Nope... the standard model is a quantum theory! (the standard model is a 
quantum theory that already includes special relativity, so you could claim 
that there's two models of the universe - the standard model and general 
relativity!)

comments.author: Mike P

comments.text:
No one said it was blind acceptance, Mr. Sane. We theorized a particle 
because we had a gap in the standard model. We found a new particle that 
fits within our expected parameters for such a particle. There is still no 
way (currently) to know what this particle does, or whether it is truly an 
excitation of the field, because we cannot accurately observe the field. 
Even if we could, there's no way to know (yet) if that's the field we're 
observing, or if we're discovering something not approached by the current 
standard model. Like gravity.

An educated guess, however probable, is still a guess. We may have found a 
"higgs boson" or we may have found something of which we've never thought.

But thank you for your input just the same.
comments.author: Jeremy Rutherford

comments.text:
So basically, while trying to find out where mass comes from, they invented 
a new particle theory that has to do with the completely unobserved higgs 
field. Since the rest of particle physics has been pretty sound, this must 
be too. Oh, and we observed an unknown particle which has a very small 
mass, so it must be a higgs-boson. I could never pass this off as 
legitimate. Even though I understand where they're coming from, I don't 
like observing an effect and assuming the cause. We observed the sun "move" 
through the sky, and assumed it was because the sun was moving around us. 
We all saw how that turned out.﻿
comments.author: Jeremy Rutherford

I would recommend to you a book by Sean Carrol called 'the particle at the

comments.author: Google sucks cock

comments.text:
actually the higgs boson is massive; so massive that it decays extremely 
quickly and is incredibly hard to make. According to quantum field theory, 
everything has a respective field; by everything, I mean everything. Bosons 
(force-carrying particles) like photons have the electromagnetic field, the 
gluon (a strong nuclear force, which holds nucleons together) also has its 
'gluon' field... every particle arises from a field. So by discovering this 
massive higgs boson, we've discovered the higgs field, which was theorized 
for decades by physicists who saw the weak nuclear forces and the breaking 
of symmetry between them as evidence that the higgs field has to exist.
I can explain this further, but there is substantial theoretical and 
experimental evidence for this now. Then again, one alternative discovery 
could change everything, and we're still looking out for it.

comments.author: Sabin Kim

comments.text:
No. The Higgs theory says the field is always there. Particles that 
interact with the field have mass, particles that don't interact with the 
field, are massless. The higgs-boson, they say, is just sort of an 
"interference" in the field.
comments.author: DesertstormPT

comments.text:
Hold on a second. It sounds like you're saying that the 'fields' exist as 
entities of their own. My understanding was that the electric field, etc 
was a mathematical construct describing what the force would be if mass, 
charge, etc was somewhere acting on a unit mass/charge at that point. The 
electric 'field' is caused by the photons not the other way round. Same 
with the Higgs?
comments.author: zardozcs

comments.text:
Wait what? Light can't have mass, that's the whole reason behind the higgs 
theory. Massless particles are particles that don't interact with the higgs 
field. Also any amount of mass and light wouldn't be able to travel at the 
speed...of light.
comments.author: DesertstormPT
